official-title.#text:
To encourage the use of medical checklists through
		  research, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the
			 following bill; which was referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text:
Research into
			 medical checklist development and efficacy

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , acting through the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall conduct research and a
			 study, in accordance with the requirements of this section, regarding the
			 development and efficacy of medical checklists.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Center for Quality Improvement and Patient Safety

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the

shall conduct research and a study
			 regarding the following:

text.#text:
In
			 carrying out

Testing of
			 different models of medical checklists to measure the effect of checklist
			 format, length, and design for different clinical tasks on—

adoption of
			 checklists by health care professionals;

time spent by
			 health care professionals on the clinical task of interest; and

reliable
			 completion of health care procedures.

Examination of
			 checklist development and use in other industries, such as commercial aviation
			 and nuclear power, and the feasibility of applying and adapting methodology
			 developed in those industries to the health care industry in a way that would
			 result in health care quality improvement.

Identification of
			 organizational characteristics needed to effectively implement the use of
			 medical checklists in health care settings.

Measurement of the
			 effects of the use of medical checklists on patient safety and health
			 outcomes.

Identification of
			 health care procedures for which the development and use of medical checklists
			 would be beneficial.

Investigation of
			 the development, implementation, and use of available medical checklists,
			 including checklists for safe surgery and central line insertion and
			 maintenance, to inform further medical checklist development.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall ensure that each aspect of the research and study conducted
			 under

is examined across a variety of health care provider
			 characteristics, medical procedures, patient populations, and other factors
			 that could affect the use of medical checklists.

shall make available to the public the results of the study conducted
			 under

and shall disseminate such results to patient safety
			 organizations listed pursuant to

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 924(d) of the Public Health Service
			 Act
There are authorized to be appropriated

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}prop.#tail: such sums as may be necessary for each of

header.#text:
Coordinating
			 medical checklists and health information technology systems

text.#text:
The HIT Policy Committee in the Office of the National
			 Coordinator for Health Information Technology (as established in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
) shall develop policy
			 recommendations regarding—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 3002
			 of the Public Health Service Act

text.#text:
the extent to
			 which the use of medical checklists should be incorporated into health
			 information technology systems; and

measures to
			 determine the effectiveness of such use.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the
			 HIT Policy Committee may consider the following areas:

text.#text: In making recommendations under

The ease with
			 which medical checklists in electronic formats can be used by health care
			 professionals.

The effect of the
			 availability of medical checklists in electronic formats on the adoption and
			 use of medical checklists by health care professionals.

The effect of the
			 use of medical checklists in electronic formats on the time spent by health
			 care professionals on medical procedures.

The ability of the
			 health information technology system to collect data on patient safety and
			 health outcomes that could be analyzed to aid in the design and update of
			 medical checklists.

The ease with
			 which medical checklists in electronic formats can be updated on an ongoing
			 basis based on evidence from medical research and local experience.

The capability of
			 health information technology systems to collect data, where applicable,
			 regarding the use of medical checklists by health care clinicians and
			 providers, and any relation between that use and patient safety and health
			 outcomes.

header.#text:
Institute of
			 medicine study on further medical checklist research

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall enter
			 into an agreement with the Institute of Medicine and the National Academy of
			 Engineering of the National Academies to conduct a study in accordance with
			 this section.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Secretary of Health and Human Services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall ensure that the study conducted under this section—

text.#text: The

reviews available
			 medical checklists and similar quality improvement techniques, data on the
			 adoption and use of such techniques by health care professionals, and evidence
			 of the efficacy of such techniques in relation to patient safety and health
			 outcomes;

reviews the degree
			 to which there is sufficient evidence with which to develop new medical
			 checklists and, if such evidence is insufficient, identifies areas requiring
			 further study in order to develop such evidence; and

determines whether
			 the availability of an increased number of medical checklists would improve
			 patient safety and health outcomes and, if so, identifies methods for using
			 recent medical research to develop new medical checklists.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall ensure that the agreement entered into under

provides that the study conducted under such subsection will consider the
			 perspectives of—

text.#text: The

various types of
			 health care professionals in various types of health care settings;

individuals
			 conducting academic research in health care quality; and
patients.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall ensure that the
			 agreement entered into under

provides that relevant agencies and
			 organizations with expertise on medical checklists will be consulted during the
			 study conducted under such subsection, including the following:
